unknown_responses.rationale: The segment states a worry, not a capability or preparedness measure.
The segment states a worry, not a capability or preparedness measure.
The phrase 'women in particular don’t take oral PrEP' describes a limitation on the use/effectiveness of a capability.
The phrase 'Yes, PrEP works. But if you don’t take it, it don’t work' describes the condition for an existing prevention method to be effective.
The phrase 'I think it would probably work well' describes a hopeful future possibility related to effectiveness.
The phrase 'we don’t have efficacious PrEP for women' states a limitation on the practical effectiveness of a capability.
The phrase 'it is not hitting it out of the park' states a limitation on the practical effectiveness of a capability.
The phrase 'having a strategic vision for NIAID' refers to planning/preparedness.
The phrase 'We’re working on a new refresh of our strategic plan' describes ongoing planning activity.
The phrase 'We’re working on a new refresh of our strategic plan' describes ongoing planning activity.
The phrase 'We really want a living document that’s going to be refreshed annually' describes the nature of a plan.
The segment asks about 'metrics for H5N1', referring to components of a plan/surveillance system.
The phrase 'I would love to see the promise of the malaria interventions realized' describes a hopeful future possibility.
The phrase 'The monoclonal antibodies and the new vaccine... actually reduced malaria' describes the effectiveness of interventions.
The phrase 'inclusion of these women in the study is such a signal achievement' describes a positive aspect of research/development.
The phrase 'you could make a huge dent' describes a potential future impact based on a strategy.
The phrase 'could create a path for serious control' describes a potential future outcome.
The segment states a personal feeling ('I’m encouraged'), not a capability or preparedness measure.
The phrase 'There’s still work to do, but the Gates Foundation-funded study... will be very interesting' describes ongoing development and future potential findings.
The phrase 'Hopefully we’ll make some inroads there. And we’ll see what happens with HIV' describes hopeful future progress and uncertainty.
The phrase 'I don’t think we’re going to end it by 2030' states a belief about the lack of a certain future capability.
The segment expresses doubt about an idea, not a capability or preparedness measure.
The phrase 'we can aim for some incredible game-changing interventions by 2030' describes a hopeful future possibility.
The segment reports detection of the virus, not capabilities or preparedness.
The phrase 'chickens... will be slaughtered and buried, while exports... will be restricted' describes planned response measures.
The phrase 'nearly 2 million chickens will have been culled' describes the scale of a response measure.
The segment provides population data, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment reports a past outbreak and culling numbers, not current capabilities or preparedness.
The segment reports a past outbreak and culling numbers, not current capabilities or preparedness.
The phrase 'South Korea last week confirming another case in an outbreak that has led to the culling' reports detection and response measures elsewhere.
The phrase 'Czech authorities will cull nearly 140,000 turkey and chickens' describes a planned response measure.
The segment describes the location and type of infection and a past case, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment reports cases in other countries, not capabilities or preparedness.
The phrase 'another farm... was in a 3-kilometre sanitary radius' describes a safeguard, and 'authorities would decide on possible culling' describes a planned future action.
The segment describes a consequence of a safeguard, not the safeguard itself.
The phrase 'Chickens have been in bird flu lockdown' describes an implemented safeguard/response measure.
The segment explains the reason for a consequence of a safeguard, not the safeguard itself.
The phrase 'When the measures are lifted, eggs will go back to being free-range' describes a future possibility.
The segment explains the reason for a safeguard, not the safeguard itself.
The phrase 'birds will be able to go outside again' describes a future possibility contingent on risk reduction.
The phrase 'France has been trialling bird flu vaccines' describes a development capability.
The segment states the purpose of measures, not the measures themselves.
The segment states developments raised concerns, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment reports outbreaks, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment reports developments including infected animals and a human case, not capabilities or preparedness.
The phrase 'the agency is taking bird flu seriously' describes an attitude/approach, and 'the virus has already been well studied' describes existing knowledge/capability.
The phrase 'farmworkers... may need to take precautions' describes a potential future preparedness measure.
The phrase 'we’ve been studying it, and frankly, we’ve been preparing for avian flu for 20 years' describes existing knowledge/development and preparedness.
The segment describes virus behavior, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment reports detection/spread, not capabilities or preparedness.
The phrase 'tens of millions of chickens have died from the virus or been killed to stop outbreaks' describes impact and a response measure (culling).
The segment reports detection, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment reports detection/spread, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment provides historical context, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment provides historical statistics, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment reports a past human case, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment reports symptoms and outcome of a past case, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment reports a recent human case, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment reports symptoms of a recent case, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment describes general symptoms, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment describes variability in symptoms, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment reports historical instances of spread, not current capabilities or preparedness.
The segment states uncertainty and concern, not capabilities or preparedness.
The phrase 'We don’t have a magic forcefield, an invisible shield' states a lack of a safeguard/capability.
The segment states a concern, not a capability or preparedness measure.
The segment states potential future impacts, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment describes economic impact, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment provides factual statistics, not capabilities or preparedness.
The phrase 'Colombia has restricted the import of beef' describes a response measure taken by another country.
The segment provides factual background information, not capabilities or preparedness.
The phrase 'the agency said the ban includes beef products' describes the details of a response measure taken elsewhere.
The phrase 'Colombia imposed temporary restrictions' describes a response measure taken by another country.
The segment describes a consequence of a response measure, not the measure itself.
The phrase 'it will require dairy cattle moving between states to be tested' describes a planned future response measure.
The phrase 'The measures aim to contain the spread' describes the goal of response measures.
The segment reports a human case and symptom, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment expresses opinion/impact of a measure, not the measure itself or a capability.
The segment describes diplomatic activity, not capabilities or preparedness related to the threat.
The segment describes a request for information, not capabilities or preparedness.
The phrase 'We are responding to their requests for information' describes an action taken as a response measure.
The segment reports what was not disclosed, not capabilities or preparedness.
The phrase 'conservationists call for international funding to help stop the disease spreading' suggests a response action.
The phrase 'could affect vast numbers... unless international funding is secured' describes a potential future impact and a condition for preventing it (securing funding).
The phrase 'teams... have buried hundreds of dead birds' describes a response measure taken.
The phrase 'confirmed the H5N1 outbreak after analysing samples' describes detection/surveillance activity.
The segment describes seasonal context, threat, and observation, not capabilities or preparedness.
The phrase 'surveillance and control' refers to preparedness and response measures.
The phrase 'Many low- to-middle-income countries have limited conservation funds' describes a limitation on resources/capability.
The segment describes a resource situation, not capabilities or preparedness itself.
The segment describes a challenge/limitation, not capabilities or preparedness itself.
The segment states the importance of a response characteristic, not a measure itself.
The phrase 'having staff on the ground with the resources that enable them to act is essential' describes essential components of response/capability.
The phrase 'written to ask the UK government to help fund the surveillance and disposal' describes an action taken to support surveillance and disposal (response measures).
The phrase 'we should at least be offering assistance' suggests a response/policy action.
The phrase 'monitoring the Bijol Islands and digging holes in the sand to bury dead birds' describes surveillance and response measures.
The segment reports findings, not capabilities or preparedness.
The segment describes the experience of a response measure, not the measure itself or capability.
